note.p: This letter in written on a single thin piece of blue-lined paper as the writing on the opposite side shows through. The singular, vertical jagged edge on the left side of the paper suggests that the paper was torn from a notebook or journal. The paper is approximately 8 x 9.75 inches in dimension. Anderson wrote the letter in brown ink and folded the letter three times( once crosswise and twice length-wise) to create six equally-sized sections so that the letter could fit into one of his standard envelopes. On the bottom of the first page, several words are smudged perhaps as a result of moisture on the captain's hand from the summer heat or from a rapid writing pace that did not allow the ink to dry sufficiently.

projectDesc.p: This electronic edition should not be thought of as merely a replication of Anderson's original letter, rather an interpretation of such. The works in this collection represent a new academic initiative to preserve archival documents. As David Levy writes in Scrolling Forward, this document is more of a "cultural artifact" that can "teach us, if only we will listen" (6). Therefore, listen closely.

This letter, written on June 17, 1862, shows a very personal reflection of the effects of the Civil War. In this letter written from Cincinnati, from where the great majority of Anderson's letters were sent, Anderson focuses primarily on the uncertainities, vicissitudes, and suffering faced by civilians and soldiers alike in wartime. Notably, this letter is the longest in this collection at a length of approximately 650 words. The length of the letter indicates that Anderson had many emotions with which he was wrestling as a result of the war. Anderson's previous letter in this collection written on September 1, 1862, was relatively short and mentions his having recovered from a recent illness and touches on an economic matter or two. This letter, written only a couple weeks later, begins rather neutrally with details about Anderson's work during the war. From these recounts, Anderson's thoughts quickly drift to his recent outlook on the war, "I have lost all horrors that I used to entertain about war [sic] I would as soon go to war as not if I were stout and had no family." The captain writes that he would go to war in defense of the Union if he had no familial ties to hold him back. He also touches briefly on the economic devastation the Civil War inevitably will bring to the Union (and presumably the South).

Anderson then elaborates on his food cravings and the rarity of some of the most common food products. Anderson's longing for the simpler things in life like 'Butter [sic]' show how deeply the war can infiltrate one's everyday life. The portion of the letter devoted to food reinforces the homesick air found throughout the letter.

Anderson then transitions in an economic matter, asking his wife to pay a visit to John Russell (probably a local merchant) requesting payment of the money owed to the Andersons. The captain expresses concern that the family may not receive their money if his wife does not convey a sense of urgency to Mr. Russell.
In closing, Anderson writes of his children and again of food. It appears that Anderson makes a strong association between his favorite foods and home.

Both the length of the letter and the emotive language suggest that Anderson was reaching a more trying point in his time as a riverboat captain. His committment to serving in the war took away his more familiar comforts both large, like his family, and small like his favorite foods.
Levy, David M. Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age. New York: Arcade, 2001.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI < supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/. To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. bibl.title: A homesick letter to Mary Louisa Anderson written from Cincinnati on Sept. 17, 1862, by William B. Anderson

div1.p: In this letter, Anderson shows a bit of emotion as he recounts his encounters with the war thus far. Anderson writes of the impoverished life he and his fellow shipmates live and becomes nostalgic over the simpler pleasures in life like Butter [sic] and Beef [sic]. Anderson asks his wife to pay a vist to John Russell in order to collect the money that Russell owes Anderson; Anderson fears that Russell will be slow to repay if his wife does not express a strong sense of need. Anderson closes the letter optimistically speaking of great times to come with his wife and children once he returns home.
Previous letter 01 June 1862 Next letter 28 Sept 1862.

Yours Came to hand this morning
& I was glad to hear from you and pleased to learn
that the the children were well I am also well and
am still employed in the same way as a dispatch
Boat and our trips only extend down as far of late
as Andersons Ferry 18 miles we made but two yesterday
one at noon and one in the night all is quiet here
now and the majority of the stores are open but there
is nothing doing but what appertains to the war it
is thought that there will be a Battle in Kentucky
someplace soon but as it will not be in the vicinity
of the River 2I will not get a chance of witnessing
it I have heard so much of war and been so much
among soldiers that I have lost all horrors that I
used to entertain about war I would as soon go
to war as not if I were stout and had no family
for it has almost became a fashion to go all that
are left out of the military ranks are old and
decripped, and it seems as that it has became a
necessity to turn out. I will never go unless compelled
to and that in defence of my own property and for
the preservation of the Union I am sure that the South will
be completely broken up and the north greatly in
debt though the debt will be amongst the north
and the money will be left in the country and all
will be benefitted more or less with it.
over
I have not seen your mother since I last wrote
to you as I have to stay on the Boat3 I have no
opportunity of seeing any body or any thing only soldiers
guns and Cannons. We are almost tiard of this kind
of work we live almost misserably poor I have not
tasted any Butter for 4 weeks that I could stand and
as for sauce we never have any thing of the kind we
have Beef poor at that and Bakers Bred and the poorest
Kind of vegatibles I ever saw all kinds of marketting is dur
and poor the Country is as dry as a chip for all we have
showers frequenty yesterday and last night and today
is as warm a time as we have had this summer and the
Mosquitoes are the worst I ever saw. I wish you would
Call on John Russell 4 and tell him you want some
Money and keep all that you know to be good such
as U.S. 5and all Pittsburgh Banks I fear that I shall
fail to get all out of him if I don’t make frequent calls
you must let on to him that you are in need or he will
put you off. Tell all the children 6 that I am not
in war nor do I intend to go that I will come home when
the river raises and that I have some things for them
I have a fine lot of Peach stones and wattermellon seeds
saved and I will go up town some of those days after
bussiness resumes more fully and buy each of them some
thing that will please them. I have thought frequently
about about our whereabouts and pleasures nine years
ago, and how as you thought what may our position
be nine year from now. I hope that we may have no
more to mar our happiness than we have had and
that we may both live and our children live many nine
years to come. I will stop as my paper is full I will
look for a letter from you on receipt of this and hope to
hear of you and the little ones enjoying good health and happiness

div1.head: Notes
div1.note: 1. A ferry that runs between Anderson Ferry Road in Cincinnati, Ohio, and Route 8 in Northern Kentucky. Anderson Ferry has been in operation since 1817. "Cincinnati-Transit.net"

2. The Ohio River, a major river of about 975 miles flowing through the eastern central United States to create the Ohio-West Virginia, Ohio-Kentucky, Kentucky-Indiana, Illinois-Kentucky borders.Encyclopedia Brit
3. Anderson built a number of boats during this time period named the Glide, the Glide 2, the Glide 3, all of which he sold to the government. "Historic Pittsburgh"

4. Perhaps the John Russell referred to as “a prominent merchant on Liberty Street for many years” (205).
"The Bibliographical Review"
6. Captain Anderson married Louisa Fischgens on September 15, 1853, and they had five children."Historic Pittsburgh"
